articles.headline: Obama Offers Help for Small Businesses
articles.snippet: President Obama presented a series of initiatives aimed at turning around the nation’s beleaguered job market.
articles.abstract: President Obama presented a series of initiatives aimed at turning around the nation’s beleaguered job market.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama and Congress are ending the year as they began it, at work on an economic stimulus package of tax cuts and spending, with the latest effort likely to raise the total cost of antirecession measures to the $1 trillion level that some economists had urged last winter.

articles.headline: U.S. Will Settle Indian Lawsuit for $3.4 Billion
articles.snippet: Payments to settle claims about revenue in American Indian trust funds could end one of the most complicated class-action lawsuits ever brought against the U.S.
articles.abstract: Payments to settle claims about revenue in American Indian trust funds could end one of the most complicated class-action lawsuits ever brought against the U.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The federal government announced on Tuesday that it intends to pay $3.4 billion to settle claims that it has mismanaged the revenue in American Indian trust funds, potentially ending one of the largest and most complicated class-action lawsuits ever brought against the United States.

articles.headline: How U.S. Became Stage for Mexican Drug Feud
articles.snippet: Prosecutors in San Diego say kidnappers and hit men operated for years after splitting from a drug cartel.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors in San Diego say kidnappers and hit men operated for years after splitting from a drug cartel.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHULA VISTA, Calif.  Eduardo Tostado was a prosperous man whose businesses and pleasures straddled the coastal border. He owned a big house and a used-car lot in the San Diego suburbs, and a seafood restaurant in Tijuana.

articles.headline: Finding the Nerve to Cut Health Costs
articles.snippet: Recent days have offered hope that some in Congress are summoning the courage to cut wasteful health spending, and endure the scare stories that follow.
articles.abstract: Recent days have offered hope that some in Congress are summoning the courage to cut wasteful health spending, and endure the scare stories that follow.

articles.headline: Text Messages: Digital Lipstick on the Collar
articles.snippet: Divorce lawyers are increasingly seeing wronged spouses using text messages to show that a partner has strayed.
articles.abstract: Divorce lawyers are increasingly seeing wronged spouses using text messages to show that a partner has strayed.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is a question that has crossed the mind recently of anyone who has sent a cellphone text message while cheating on a spouse: What was I thinking?

articles.headline: In India, Anxiety Over the Slow Pace of Innovation
articles.snippet: Indians fret that Bangalore, and India more broadly, will remain a low-cost satellite office of the West, rather than a hotbed of entrepreneurship.
articles.abstract: Indians fret that Bangalore, and India more broadly, will remain a low-cost satellite office of the West, rather than a hotbed of entrepreneurship.
articles.lead_paragraph: BANGALORE, India  In the United States and Europe, people worry that their well-paying, high-skill jobs will be, in a word, “Bangalored”  shipped off to India.

articles.headline: Protection Chief Struggles With Madoff Claims
articles.snippet: Stephen P. Harbeck, the head of the Securities Investors Protection Corporation, has been criticized for failing to help the victims of feeder or pension funds lost in the Madoff Ponzi scheme.
articles.abstract: Stephen P. Harbeck, the head of the Securities Investors Protection Corporation, has been criticized for failing to help the victims of feeder or pension funds lost in the Madoff Ponzi scheme.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stephen P. Harbeck knows what it feels like to be under attack  in 1970, he served in Vietnam as a sniper with the fabled Seventh Cavalry, once led by Custer.

articles.headline: Reid Says Deal Resolves the Impasse on the Public Option
articles.snippet: Senators said a tentative agreement between Harry Reid, the majority leader, and 10 other Democrats would sideline but not kill a government-run health insurance plan.
articles.abstract: Senators said a tentative agreement between Harry Reid, the majority leader, and 10 other Democrats would sideline but not kill a government-run health insurance plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, said Tuesday night that he and a group of 10 Democratic senators had reached “a broad agreement” to resolve a dispute over a proposed government-run health insurance plan, which has posed the biggest obstacle to passage of sweeping health care legislation.
articles.byline: By Robert Pear and David M. Herszenhorn
